comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Charles Neufeld was an Austrian merchant who spent twelve years as a prisoner in the Sudan, starting in 1887. He published a memoir, A Prisoner of the Khaleefa: Twelve Years' Captivity at Omduran, in 1899. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50812FE39541B728... archive.org/details/prisonerofkhalee00neufuoft Another book, Under the Rebel's Reign: A Story of Egyptian Revolt, followed in 1900: www.gutenberg.org/files/23829/23829-h/23829-h.htm

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: He was born Karl Neufeld and is found frequently under that name as well. A pretty colorful character. An 1898 account of his life through his imprisonment: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F70717F83A5D11... Here's an 1899 account of his life after he was freed from prison and went to London. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60B11F93F5414728... In November, 1915, he was reported arriving in Constantinople en route from Medina query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20E15F73C5A11738... A German Wikipedia article on an unsuccessful German expedition to establish communications and propaganda centers in Yemen during 1916 mentions that he was part of the expedition. de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stotzingen-Mission There is a further account of his life published in July, 1918 when he died in Germany. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20E15F73C5A11738... An ancestor has posted a short biographical account: www.egyptedantan.com/carlneufeld.htm There really should be a Wikipedia entry for this fellow.

comment._content: Correct link for the November 1915 NYT article above (about returning from Medina) is query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10911F8385B17738...
